content: Matt, After I clicked on the Windows Icon, did a search for settings > Personalization > Colors, I then changed "Accent Color" to "Automatic" from "Manual" which had the gray color selected, my issue was resolved. Thanks again for pointing me in the right direction. Bob

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
The location of your IMAP account is as shown in attached screenshot. That is a bit unique. To see your files, a screenshot of the 1obgur6I.default folder itself may help, plus a screenshot of the contents of the imapmail.sbd follder, and, if present, a screenshot of the 1obgur6I.default\Mail folder and the 1obgur6I.default\Mail\Local Folders folder. Those should display whatever message folders are there.

Another possibility is that you may have a prior profile, not longer used. You can check that by viewing the 

...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder to see if other profiles exist. If so, look there for the same folders, such as the Mail and/or imapmail folders.

A comment: the account shown is IMAP. if those folders were removed from the online account, they would no longer appear in Thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content:
My experience is that automated backups do not work well with Thunderbird. The safe way to do a backup is to backup the entire profile all at once when thunderbird is not running. That is the best assurance that a restore will work flawlessly. I routinely see posts here where a proprietary backup could not be properly restored and had to be done piecemeal. I'm not a technical guru, but part of the challenge is that thunderbird does not release its hold on files, causing a backup done while thunderbird is running to be incomplete or corrupt. My personal approach is to run a daily backup at a time when I know thunderbird is not running. I also run a standalone backup weekly for safety. I share here my technique:

here is the info in brief steps:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: Puzzling that you post to this help forum to state your failed efforts because you did NOT ask for help. People routinely set up Outlook accounts here with little effort. True, importing addressbooks, such as in CSV format, can be challenging, not just with thunderbird but elsewhere. And doing so in Thunderbird is a simple set of steps that we regularly share with those who ask. I regret your failure to successfully install Thunderbird and wish you well in installing another one. Emclient and Mailbird advertise a simple import process, so that may prove a better route for you.
creator: davidsk

content:
I suggest you log onto your online account to see what is there. Is this a POP account? A possibility is that the archive folder was created as a subfolder of the inbox, which would leave the inbox as still full. You can check this by

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. click either the imapmail folder if IMAP account or the Mail folder for POP
  4. now, click the account folder so the message folders, such as inbox, sent, etc, appear
  5. do a screenshot of that and post back. that will help in assessing and making suggestions on the issue.
creator: davidsk

content:
The passwords can be view by this: - click setting>privacy&security - click the savedpasswords button and then showpasswords button - in doing so, you may be prompted for the PCs initial signin password

the passwords shown are the ones that thunderbird is using. that is, if you are getting 'invalid password' errors, that means that the passwords in thunderbird are no longer correct. in that case, you need to contact the email provider to get a fresh password. Also, if the email account uses a secondary password (such as Gmail), that is not the actual password.
creator: davidsk
